comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Thanks State Records NSW.

Alas, no name headbands on the sailors' hats, but the hi-res is astounding, showing a wealth of detail.  The pressure gauge looks like a rudder direction indicator. The clock says 14:05. 

There is something engraved on the cannon muzzle which looks like a "D", a name and a date (1883?) .  It might be the name of the ship, or the name of the cannon manufacturer.  Can anyone decipher it?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: You're right beachcomberaustralia - its a rudder angle indicator. I can't decipher the engraving on the cannon. The more I look at it the more it morphs into different letter possibilities!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Yes, it looks like a "D". Next word could start with "v" ... VERNON?

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Interesting picture, can any of our resident nautical experts come up with the answer, which frigate is this?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I initially thought that the big guns shown here had grooves in the outer surface of the jackets. But on zooming in I realised that the jackets are in fact highly polished and that what I thought were grooves are really reflections (!). There are a few pics around the web of deck mounted broadside guns dating from about the 1880s which show a similar carriage set-up to this. These ones look to be quite big...maybe ?Armstrong 7 inch or larger. The shells lined up to the side look like big stuff. There's also a fairly large calibre ?4 barrelled Nordenfelt machine-gun mounted on the deck above left. So this is probably not a ferry or a surveying vessel. We need some kind of image enhancing tool to read what's stamped on the muzzle of the big gun in the front. I gather that some gun makers stamped a serial number and date of manufacture on the muzzle, but there seems to be a bit more than just a serial number here.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Check out this gun - www.flickr.com/photos/9977224@N06/1374682442

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Another mystery cannon for you.  I am afraid guns are a bore (!) to me;  my father was in the Royal Artillery -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3283283663/]

My most recent thoughts on this photo is that it is not really the unnamed ship which is the subject.  There are trees and a building behind.  Is that Government House, or is the ship in Sutherland Dock ?  ie part of the Public Works Dept record of the new Dock's capabilities ?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: If only that sailor had taken a step to his left we might be able to see the rooftop a little better....

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: If anyone is interested there are a few low-res pics of HMS Penguin taken in Brisbane in 1895, in the Hume Collection, which is held at the Fryer Lib at UQ, eg. - www.library.uq.edu.au/fryer/hume/web/779.html The ship in this pic certainly appears to have come out of the same mould as HMS Penguin...presumably it too was built in the 1870s and was perhaps re-armed and refitted to extend its use-by date...The Hume Collection contains a few other interesting pics of ships...including this one which shows a gun set up similar to the one in this Archives Office of NSW pic www.library.uq.edu.au/fryer/hume/web/788.html I bet the gun crews weren't afforded the luxury of hearing protection!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The Col Sec's Office has a somewhat similar look to the building in the background - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=29697 ...the parapet and decorative bits...the chimneys...Also see this pic - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=385884 where Beachcomber has indicated the Col Sec's Office...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Good spot! It does look very like the top left (SE) corner of the Colonial Secretary's Office finials, urns and chimneys in your first link (also on Flickr - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2733974091/ ). Before the mansard roof and dome was added. Which (possibly) puts the Frigate in Farm Cove; we are looking west - and the shadows are right for the time of day (14:05 see note). But we still need a name for the friggit Frigate.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Good stuff!! It does look likely to be the roof of the Colonial Secretary's Office in the background!
-AG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I made a list of 22+ possible ships on the Australian Station at the time (1880-1900), and discounted them one by one using Trove Pictures and Google. The strongest evidence imho is for HMS 'Opal' (1875), which was on the Australian Station from 1885-90 (which fits with the Colonial Secretary's building parapets!). The distinctive wheelhouse behind the aft mast, the glass lamp on a pillar in front of it, and the machine guns mounted in white turrets on the side, show up in a Henry King photo. Luckily Henry King photographed the ship in great detail, and the original glass negative is zoomable here - from.ph/31442 . Also at - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/30675 . I am not 100% sure of this - It could possibly be HMS 'Emerald', 'Danae', 'Rapid', or another. Needless to say, 'Opal' was the last on my list, and I need a cup of tea, a Bex, and a good lie down!

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: That's darned good work Beachcomber, are you going to post that great old picture of the ship?

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: That's pretty good Beachcomber!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63610891 - apart from what looks like a skirting board on the side of the skylight (or whatever the nautical term is) this 1890 Illustrated Sydney News pic is a good match...I suspect the rail shown in the ISN pic might have been put up when the skylight windows were closed...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Sorry, only just found this! Many thanks! I think the rail is in the middle of the two halves of the skylight. The time is 09:35 - I wonder what the photographer did for 4 1/2 hours?! I think that is proof enough (phew!) that this is H.M.S. 'Opal', in May 1890, and the photographer was "Kerry and Jones".

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Brilliant work quasymody! Somehow I missed it too! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Not necessarily the same photographer. My bet it was a Government Printing Office photographer more interested in the ship than taking the officers portraits. ['Kerry and Jones' refers to none other than Charles Kerry, and his partner C. D. Jones.
At 17 he [Kerry] joined Alexander Henry Lamartiniere's photographic studio and about 1883 became a partner. Soon afterwards Lamartiniere absconded with Kerry's small capital, but he carried on in partnership with C. D. Jones, paid off the firm's debts and turned a small portrait studio into the colony's largest photographic organization.
- adb.anu.edu.au/biography/kerry-charles-henry-6940]
